When using the Parameterized RunWith annotation for your unit tests,
the on=
ly way to identify a particular parameter is by the index by
which it appea=
red in your 2d object array. So your results look like this:

myTest[0] (Pa=
ssed)
myTest[1] (Passed)
...
myTest[k] (Failed)
...
myTest[n] (Passed)

Aw,=
 shucks. test #k failed. So you go to your java file, count down,
one, two.=
.. all the way to the k'th element. Ah. This must be the one
that failed. 
=

Really, it's fairly annoying. 

I've taken to making the first parameter o=
f each element a text label
for the test. It doesn't help much, because you=
 still only see
myTest[k] (Failed) but when you click on it (in Eclipse), I=
've used
the text label portion of the asserts to tell me what I was lookin=
g at. 

Uh. To be clearer...

@RunWith(Parameterized.class)
public class Te=
stStuff {
@Parameters
public static Collection data() {
    return Arrays.a=
sList( new Object[][] {
        { "TestTwoPlusTwo", 2, 2, 4 },
        { "T=
estTwoPlusThree", 2, 3, 5 },
        ...
    });
}

public TestStuff(String=
 friendlyName, p1, p2, p3) {
    this.friendlyName =3D friendlyName;
    th=
is.param1 =3D p1;
    this.param2 =3D p2;
    this.param3 =3D p3;
}

@Test
=
public void myTest() {
assertTrue(testName + " failed", param1 + param2 =3D=
=3D param3);
}
}

But like I said, it only means your error log/failure tra=
ce is a
little more descriptive. Has anyone else done anything similar, and=

perhaps done it better?

Gabriel.
